description.title: IOW %

description.title: IRQ %

description.definition: Percentage of CPU time spent on low priority processes and been niced.
description.title: Nice

description.definition: CPU for system processes. The  time  the  CPU  has  spent  running  the  kernel  and  its processes.
description.title: Sys

description.definition: CPU time spent idle
description.title: Idle

description.definition: Input Output Wait
description.title: IOW

description.definition: CPU time spent servicing/handling hardware Interrupt Requests
description.title: IRQ

description.definition: CPU time spent servicing/handling software Interrupt Requests
description.title: SIRQ

description.definition: Time spent running non kernel code. (user time, including nice time)
description.title: us

description.definition: Time spent running kernel code. (system time)
description.title: sy

description.definition: Time spent idle.
description.title: id

description.definition: Time spent waiting for IO.
description.title: wa

description.definition: Virtual set size. Total accessible address space of a process. This size also includes memory that may not be resident in RAM like mallocs that have been allocated but not written to. VSS is of very little use for determing real memory usage of a process.
description.title: Vss

description.definition: Resident set size. The total memory actually held in RAM for a process. RSS can be misleading, because it reports the total all of the shared libraries that the process uses, even though a shared library is only loaded into memory once regardless of how many processes use it. RSS is not an accurate representation of the memory usage for a single process.
description.title: Rss

description.definition: (Proportional set size)The Pss Total includes all Zygote allocations (weighted by their sharing across processes, as described in the PSS definition above), it reports the proportional size of its shared libraries, i.e. if three processes all use a shared library that has 30 pages, that library will only contribute 10 pages to the PSS that is reported for each of the three processes. PSS is a very useful number because when the PSS for all processes in the system are summed together, that is a good representation for the total memory usage in the system. When a process is killed, the shared libraries that contributed to its PSS will be proportionally distributed to the PSS totals for the remaining processes still using that library. In this way PSS can be slightly misleading, because when a process is killed, PSS does not accurately represent the memory returned to the overall system.
description.title: Pss

description.definition: (Unique set size) The Private Dirty number is the actual RAM committed to only your app’s heap, composed of your own allocations and any Zygote allocation pages that have been modified since forking your app’s process from Zygote. The total private memory for a process, i.e. that memory that is completely unique to that process. USS is an extremely useful number because it indicates the true incremental cost of running a particular process. When a process is killed, the USS is the total memory that is actually returned to the system. USS is the best number to watch when initially suspicious of memory leaks in a process.
description.title: Uss
